Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was remarked that monetary transmission through the banking sector had been effective, partly because the balance sheets of banks had been stronger at the start of the pandemic than before the financial crisis of 2008.\n                '}]

interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in this context it was pointed out that, in some countries, real estate transactions had already started to pick up again, presumably owing to reduced uncertainty about the future interest rate path.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that reduced uncertainty about future interest rates is leading to an increase in real estate transactions, implying a more accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

"Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: credit conditions for households and firms remained accommodative.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:42:24,648 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that credit conditions are 'accommodative', which is a key phrase associated with a dovish stance, suggesting that the ECB is maintaining a supportive monetary policy."
}

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: us commodity futures trading commission numbers suggested that the market remained positioned for an appreciation of the euro.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:42:29,257 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that the market is positioned for an appreciation of the euro, which suggests a decrease in the value of other currencies, implying a dovish stance."
}

of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it was therefore likely that the recent slowdown reflected a combination of both structural and cyclical factors.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",

fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: some comfort was drawn from these recent developments, as they suggested that the recent weakness in headline and core inflation had not had a negative impact on expectations.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:42:37,706 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that recent developments have not had a negative impact on expectations, implying a stable economic situation, which is a neutral stance."
}

is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: but it was also noted that the latest developments cautioned against simply extrapolating the very large impact that had been included in the september projections.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence does not provide a clear indication of the ECB's stance, as it only notes caution against extrapolating previous projections, without expressing a specific opinion or direction."
}

decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. "label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that underlying inflation is expected to increase, supported by the ECB's monetary policy measures, economic expansion, and rising wage growth, suggesting a hawkish stance."

stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the proposed extension of the calendar-based leg of the governing council’s forward guidance was generally seen as underpinning the monetary accommodation needed to support inflation converging towards the governing council’s aim.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the extension of the forward guidance is necessary to support inflation convergence, implying a need for continued monetary accommodation, which is a dovish stance."

housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank 2025-05-03 23:42:57,403 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates slower growth in the second half of 2018, which will lead to a lower projection for growth in 2019, suggesting a dovish stance as the central bank may want to stimulate the economy."
}

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: retaining the existing flexibility in pepp reinvestments was seen as a prudent approach to countering risks to the monetary policy transmission mechanism related to the pandemic, which still persisted in the current market environment.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",

housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the eurosystem cash collateral facility had been instrumental in mitigating pressures in the repo market.\n                '}]

demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: overall, the governing council assessed that there were still significant upside risks to the inflation outlook.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights significant upside risks to the inflation outlook, suggesting that inflation may increase, which may encourage the ECB to contract the money supply."
}

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: reference was made to producer price inflation, which had rebounded somewhat despite the recent decline in energy prices, as well as to the gdp deflator, which indicated somewhat higher underlying inflation and suggested upward potential for future hicp inflation if the two measures converged over the medium term, as had typically been the case in the past.\n                '}]

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, core inflation was expected to decline over the projection horizon owing to the fading impact of the pandemic, the easing of bottlenecks and the indirect contribution of the current surge in energy prices falling away.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a decline in core inflation, which suggests a decrease in inflationary pressures, leading to a dovish stance."
}

stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices,
