prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: rates on corporate loans had been moving sideways in nominal terms (and therefore upwards in real terms), dampening demand for external finance.\n                '}]

housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: with regard to the implementation of the app, members welcomed findings indicating the effectiveness of the corporate sector purchase programme (cspp) in easing market financing conditions and, hence, supporting the transmission of monetary policy.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights the effectiveness of the corporate sector purchase programme in easing market financing conditions, which suggests that the ECB's accommodative monetary policy is working, implying a dovish stance."
}

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: rising construction costs were expected to put a break on growth in housing investment.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:43:37,847 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a potential slowdown in housing investment due to rising construction costs, suggesting a dovish stance as the ECB may need to stimulate the economy."
}

is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the view was also expressed that near-term risks were now balanced, with reference made to recent rebounds in survey-based indicators and some hard data.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that near-term risks are balanced, indicating a neutral stance, as it neither leans towards a dovish nor hawkish perspective."

Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the higher volatility went hand in hand with a deterioration in market liquidity.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a deterioration in market liquidity, which may suggest a need for the ECB to adopt a more accommodative monetary policy stance to stabilize the market."
}

deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the five-year forward inflation-linked swap rate five years ahead stood at 1.7%.\n                '}]

"justification": "The forward inflation-linked swap rate is below the ECB's 2% inflation target, indicating lower inflation expectations, which may prompt a dovish monetary policy stance."

label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{ecb}{nine} Economic Status, Euro Value Change, Energy Prices, House Prices, Foreign Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, this was very different from a scenario in which the euro area entered a prolonged period of negative growth.\n                '}]

Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the increase in interest rates was expected to lead to higher financing costs for governments.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:44:01,328 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that higher interest rates will lead to higher financing costs for governments, which may reduce borrowing and spending, thus reducing inflationary pressures."
}

actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at the same time, it was cautioned that credit risks and the probability of default of non-financial corporations were increasing as the crisis endured.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights increasing credit risks and default probabilities of non-financial corporations, indicating a potential economic slowdown, which may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance."

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: mr lane reviewed the global environment and the recent economic and monetary developments in the euro area.\n                '}]

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: although measures of underlying inflation had generally remained muted, there were indications of a mild increase in line with previous expectations.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a mild increase in underlying inflation, which is in line with previous expectations, suggesting no change in the ECB's stance."

to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in particular, even a fundamentally sound sovereign could be brought to the brink of default owing to a self-fulfilling dynamic involving market participants demanding higher risk premia based on a fear that the market might become illiquid.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 23:44:20,413 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights the risk of a sovereign default due to market participants' fear, indicating a potential economic downturn, which may prompt the ECB to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance."
}

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Euro Value Change} & Euro depreciates relative to other global currencies. & Euro appreciates relative to other global currencies. & Minimal or no change in the Euro Value relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, increase. & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{House Prices} & Housing prices in the Eurozone increase. & Housing price in the Eurozone decrease. & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & European Union trade deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: since the governing council’s meeting on 9-10 march, commodity prices had risen, with brent crude oil prices up by 6.5% to around usd 42 per barrel and non-oil commodity prices up by 2.5% in us dollar terms, while the nominal effective exchange rate of the euro had appreciated by 0.4% vis-à-vis 38 major trading partners.\n                '}]

value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Future inflation expectations are high, suggesting that higher inflation may be to come, and the ECB may want to start contracting the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Current interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates a significant decline in global trade, suggesting economic slowdown that may prompt policymakers to adopt a more dovish monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central Bank}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & HICP Inflation increases or is higher than targeted 2\\% rate, Inflation risk present on high side, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth increases. & HICP Inflation decreases or is lower than targeted 2\\% rate, Eurozone GDP and/or Eurozone GDP growth decreases, Economic growth risk present on the downside. & Inflation rate remains stable around 2\\%, Economic growth remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. relative to other global currencies. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy Prices} & Energy prices in the Eurozone, including oil and or natural gas prices, deficit increases. & European Union trade deficit decreases, external (to Eurozone) demand for EU goods falls. & When foreign nation outside of the Eurozone or European Union is discussed. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets} & Inflation, Economic Growth higher than expected, Increase in key ECB interest rates, Selling off of Securities purchased through Purchasing Programs). & Inflation, Economic Growth lower than expected, Decrease in key ECB interest rates, Increase in or continued exercise of purchasing programs. & Inflation, Economic Growth near expectations, Unchanged ECB interest rates (Deposit Facility, Fixed Rate Tender, Marginal Lending), no change in purchasing program policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Money supply is high, High Capitalization of banks, M2 decreases, Low demand for loans. & Money supply is low, Low capitalization for banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. Ex. "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: turning to money and credit, annual growth in broad money (m3) had remained robust at 5.0% in january, after 4.7% in december, supported by the low interest rates, as well as the impact of the targeted longer-term refinancing operations (tltros) and the asset purchase programme (app).\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions low interest rates and the impact of the targeted longer-term refinancing operations and the asset purchase programme, which suggests an accommodative monetary policy stance."
}

banks, M2 increases, Increased demand for loans. fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in Nations, ECB Expectations/Actions/Assets, Money Supply, Key Words/Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the general state of the Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s secondary objectives, which does not directly relate to immediate monetary policy actions.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{European Central "Banks reported, on balance, an increase in firms’ demand for loans or drawing of credit lines in the second quarter of 2022". & N/A & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Indicating a focus on ``price stability\'\' and ``sustained growth.\'\' & When the stance is ``accommodative,\'\' a focus on ``maximum employment.\'\' & Use of phrases like ``mixed,\'\' ``moderate,\'\' ``reaffirmed.\'\' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & When unemployment rate decreases or earnings increase. & When unemployment rate increases or earnings decrease. & Unemployment rate or growth is unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:ecb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the size of the proposed envelope was calculated to make a significant contribution to offsetting the pandemic-related downward shift in the projected inflation path.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the ECB is taking measures to counteract the negative impact of the pandemic on inflation, suggesting a dovish stance to support the economy."

Eurozone economy, incorporating factors such as inflation trends, GDP performance, and overall growth risks. \n    \\item \\emph{Euro Value Change}: A sentence that addresses variations in the Euro\'s value relative to other global currencies, whether it appreciates or depreciates. \n    \\item \\emph{Energy Prices}: A sentence relating to changes in energy costs within the Eurozone, including fluctuations in oil and natural gas prices. \n    \\item \\emph{House Prices}: A sentence that discusses shifts in the residential real estate market within the Eurozone, particularly changes in housing prices. \n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence concerning trade relations between the European Union and non-Eurozone countries, highlighting changes in trade deficits or external demand for EU goods. \n    \\item \\emph{ECB Expectations, Actions, and Assets}: A sentence describing the European Central Bank\'s economic outlook and policy responses, including interest rate adjustments and modifications to asset purchasing programs. \n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence discussing the availability of monetary resources in the Eurozone, reflecting trends in bank capitalization, changes in the M2 measure, and shifts in loan demand. \n    \\item \\emph{Key Words and Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific terminology or expressions frequently used by policymakers to indicate a dovish, hawkish, or neutral stance. \n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence addressing labor market conditions, including fluctuations in unemployment rates and changes in salaries. \n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The purchasing managers’ index for manufacturing export orders had fallen into contractionary territory in march owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n owing to the war in Ukraine and lockdowns in China.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Slowing economic growth in the manufacturing sector is highlighted, signifying that the central bank may want to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy.\n    \n    \\item ``In addition, options markets had, by and large, priced out low inflation outcomes over the following five years.\'\' \\newline\n interest rates are at levels that, maintained for a sufficiently long duration, will make a substantial contribution to this goal.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The ECB reiterates that there will be no interest rate change.\n    \n    \\item ``Labour costs had also confirmed continued moderate domestic price pressures.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: High labor costs can lead to inflation, which may encourage the ECB to decrease the money supply.\n    \n    \\item ``Data on new export orders pointed to a sharp fall of global trade in the second quarter of the year.\'\' stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Against this background, it was recalled that the ECB also had secondary objectives.\'\' \\newline\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: This sentence primarily references the ECB’s
